Source: Brazilian Institute of Geography and Statistics (IBGE); Census and Statistics Department; Central Statistics Bureau of Latvia; ITU; National Communications Commission; Swedish Post and Telecom Authority
Description: Percentage of households with Internet
Notes: Can include both estimates and survey data corresponding to the proportion of households with Internet. The Internet is a world-wide public computer network. It provides access to a number of communication services including the World Wide Web and carries email;  news;  entertainment and data files. Access is not assumed to be only via a computer - it may also be by mobile phone;  games machine;  digital TV etc. The proportion of households with Internet access at home is calculated by dividing the number of in-scope households with Internet access by the total number of in-scope households. Internet users are individuals who have used the Internet (from any location) in the last 12 months. Internet can be used via a computer, mobile phone, personal digital assistant, games machine, digital TV etc.

Source: ITU; Office of the Communications Authority; Swedish Post and Telecom Authority
Description: Fixed-line broadband subscriptions per 100 inhabitants
Notes: Fixed broadband subscriptions refers to fixed subscriptions to high-speed access to the public Internet (a TCP/IP connection), at downstream speeds equal to, or greater than, 256 kbit/s. This includes cable modem, DSL, fiber-to-the-home/building, other fixed (wired)-broadband subscriptions, satellite broadband and terrestrial fixed wireless broadband. This total is measured irrespective of the method of payment. It excludes subscriptions that have access to data communications (including the Internet) via mobile-cellular networks. It should include fixed WiMAX and any other fixed wireless technologies. It includes both residential subscriptions and subscriptions for organizations.

Source: ITU; Swedish Post and Telecom Authority
Description: Mobile-cellular telephone subscriptions per 100 inhabitants
Notes: Mobile cellular telephone subscriptions are subscriptions to a public mobile telephone service that provide access to the PSTN using cellular technology. This includes (and is split into) the number of postpaid subscriptions, and the number of active prepaid accounts (i.e. that have been used during the last three months) and applies to all mobile cellular subscriptions that offer voice communications. It excludes subscriptions via data cards or USB modems, subscriptions to public mobile data services, private trunked mobile radio, telepoint, radio paging and telemetry services. There is a cap on mobile subscriptions at 130. All countries that exceed this value will receive 130 as the maximum possible value. This cap accounts for differences in SIM user behavior, including influxes in tourism, migrant workers, and other factors that can play into the over-estimation of the number of subscribers.

Description: Gap between male and female access to the Internet
Notes: This measures the gap between male and female access to the Internet. Positive values indicate that male access exceeds female access. Negative values indicate greater female connectivity. Note: The EIU has adopted a new method to calculate the gender gap ratio according to the following formula: (Male access - Female access) / Male access. Scores for past years for this indicator have been backscored to reflect this change. In past versions of the index, the EIU calculated the gender gap ratio with female access as the denominator: (Male access - Female access) / Female access.

IndicatorName: Gender gap in mobile phone access
Description: Gap between male and female access to mobile phone
Notes: This measures the gap between male and female access to mobile phones. Positive values indicate that male access exceeds female access. Negative values indicate greater female connectivity. Note: The EIU has adopted a new method to calculate the gender gap ratio according to the following formula: (Male access - Female access) / Male access. Scores for past years for this indicator have been backscored to reflect this change. In past versions of the index, the EIU calculated the gender gap ratio with female access as the denominator: (Male access - Female access) / Female access.

Description: Measure of average fixed-line broadband upload speed
Notes: This measures average fixed broadband upload speed. Averages are based on Ookla_s analysis of Speedtest data. A faster speed is a positive indicator for better performance. Note: The data source for this indicator has changed from Cisco to Ookla.  Given the different data source, current edition data may not be comparable with data from previous editions.

Description: Measure of average fixed-line broadband download speed
Notes: This measures average fixed broadband download speed. Averages are based on Ookla_s analysis of Speedtest data. A faster speed is a positive indicator for better performance. Note: The data source for this indicator has changed from Cisco to Ookla.  Given the different data source, current edition data may not be comparable with data from previous editions.

Description: Measure of how long it takes data to travel between its source and destination
Notes: This measures average fixed broadband latency. Averages are based on Ookla_s analysis of Speedtest data. A faster speed is a positive indicator for better performance. Note: The data source for this indicator has changed from Cisco to Ookla.  Given the different data source, current edition data may not be comparable with data from previous editions.

Description: Measure of average mobile upload speed
Notes: This measures average mobile upload speed. Averages are based on Ookla_s analysis of Speedtest data. A faster speed is a positive indicator for better performance. Note: The data source for this indicator has changed from Cisco to Ookla.  Given the different data source, current edition data may not be comparable with data from previous editions.

Description: Measure of average mobile download speed
Notes: This measures average mobile download speed. Averages are based on Ookla_s analysis of Speedtest data. A faster speed is a positive indicator for better performance. Note: The data source for this indicator has changed from Cisco to Ookla.  Given the different data source, current edition data may not be comparable with data from previous editions.

Description: Measure of how long it takes data to travel between its source and destination
Notes: This measures average mobile latency. Averages are based on Ookla_s analysis of Speedtest data. A faster speed is a positive indicator for better performance. Note: The data source for this indicator has changed from Cisco to Ookla.  Given the different data source, current edition data may not be comparable with data from previous editions.

Description: Total used capacity of international Internet bandwidth, in bits per second per Internet user.
Notes: Used international Internet bandwidth refers to the average traffic load (expressed in bit/s) of international fiber-optic cables and radio links for carrying Internet traffic.

Description: Percentage of the population covered by a mobile-cellular network refers to the percentage of inhabitants within range of a mobile-cellular signal;  irrespective of whether or not they are subscribers or users.
Notes: This is calculated by dividing the number of inhabitants within range of a mobile-cellular signal by the total population and multiplying by 100. 2G networks include the following mobile broadband technologies: cdmaOne, CDMA2000 1X, GSM, PDC, PHS, iDEN, and TDMA.  Note: Data quality for ITU indicators is dependent upon timely and accurate reporting from countries' telecommunication regulators and other relevant ministries.

Source: ITU; Secretary of State for Digital Advancement (SEAD)
Description: Percentage of the population covered by at least a 3G mobile network refers to the percentage of inhabitants that are within range of at least a 3G mobile-cellular signal;  irrespective of whether or not they are subscribers.
Notes: This is calculated by dividing the number of inhabitants that are covered by at least a 3G mobile-cellular signal by the total population and multiplying by 100. 3G networks include the following mobile broadband technologies: CDMA2000 1xEV-DO, CDMA2000 1xEV-DO Rev. A, CDMA2000 1xEV-DO Rev. B, WCDMA, WCDMA HSPA, and TD-SCDMA. Note: Data quality for ITU indicators is dependent upon timely and accurate reporting from countries' telecommunication regulators and other relevant ministries.

Source: ITU; Secretary of State for Digital Advancement (SEAD)
Description: Percentage of the population covered by at least an LTE/WiMAX mobile network refers to the percentage of inhabitants that live within range of LTE/LTE-Advanced;  mobile WiMAX/WirelessMAN or other more advanced mobile-cellular networks;  irrespective of whether or not they are subscribers.
Notes: This is calculated by dividing the number of inhabitants that are covered by the previously mentioned mobile-cellular technologies by the total population and multiplying by 100. It excludes people covered only by HSPA;  UMTS;  EV-DO and previous 3G technologies;  and also excludes fixed WiMAX coverage.  Note: Data quality for ITU indicators is dependent upon timely and accurate reporting from countries' telecommunication regulators and other relevant ministries.

Description: Has 5G been implemented in any city in the country either for full commercial use or for trials?
Notes: Assesses whether operators have implemented 5G New Radio (NR) technology in the country, including as part of a trial or a fuller commercial deployment. Limited availability refers to a 5G network that is present but where devices are limited to select users, usually in a testing environment. Commercial availability refers to a 5G network where any consumer can purchase a device for use on this network. Note: This indicator was included for the first time in the fourth edition.
ZERO: No, 5G has not been implemented in any city in the country
ONE: Yes, 5G has been implemented in at least one city for trials
TWO: Yes, 5G has been implemented in at least one city for full commercial or public usage

IndicatorName: Government initiatives to make Wi-Fi available
Description: Does the government provide public Wi-Fi access in the largest city in the country and is it free to connect to?
Notes: Assesses whether the network is free to join or not. _Public_ means that the Wi-Fi network and associated hotspot(s) must be accessible in a public park, library, public building, airport, train or ferry terminal.   "Largest city" means largest city in the country by population.
ZERO: No, the government does not provide public Wi-Fi access in the largest city in the country
ONE: Yes, the government does provide public Wi-Fi access in the largest city in the country
TWO: Yes, the government does provide public Wi-Fi access in the largest city and the country and it is free

IndicatorName: Private sector initiatives to make Wi-Fi available
Description: Does the largest privately-owned ISP provide public Wi-Fi access to its customers in the largest city in the country and is it free to connect to?
Notes: Assesses whether the network is free to join or not and whether the public Wi-Fi is available to anyone (general population, tourists, etc.) or just to customers of the largest ISP in the country. The largest ISP means the largest private-sector run ISP, not state-owned. "Public" means that the Wi-Fi network and associated hotspot(s) must be accessible in a public park, library, public building, airport, train or ferry terminal.  "Largest city" means largest city in the country by population.
ZERO: No, the largest privately-owned ISP does not provide public Wi-Fi access in the largest city in the country, nor does any other privately-owned ISP
ONE: Yes, either the largest privately-owned ISP or other privately-owned ISPs do provide public Wi-Fi access in the largest city in the country
TWO: Yes, either the largest privately-owned ISP or other privately-owned ISPs do provide public Wi-Fi access in the largest city in the country and it is free

Unit: Number of IXPs per 10 million inhabitants
Description: Measures the number of Internet exchange points (IXPs) in each country
Notes: IXPs are physical network access point through which major network providers connect their networks and exchange traffic. This indicator accounts for only those IXPs that are considered active.

Source: WEO-IEA; World Bank; World Energy Council
Description: Urban electrification rate (%)
Notes: Access to electricity is calculated as the percentage of population with access to electricity. Electrification data are collected from industry, national surveys and international sources.

Source: WEO-IEA; World Bank; World Energy Council
Description: Rural electrification rate (%)
Notes: Access to electricity is calculated as the percentage of population with access to electricity. Electrification data are collected from industry, national surveys and international sources.

Description: Indexed scores of the price of entry-level handset to the consumer, as a percentage of GNI per capita
Notes: Assesses the cost of an entry-level handset that is internet-enabled, expressed as a percentage of monthly GNI per capita. Note: This indicator is based on the Mobile Connectivity Index, developed by GSMA. Given changes to the Mobile Connectivity Index over time (e.g., addition or removal of countries from year to year), scores for countries may not be directly comparable between different iterations. As a result, YoY comparisons for this indicator are not available in the Inclusive Internet Index.

Description: Price of prepaid mobile data plan, 1 GB, as a percentage of monthly income
Notes: Monthly cost of a 1 GB prepaid mobile broadband data plan, expressed as a percentage of monthly GNI per capita. Note: This indicator was updated in the fourth edition to capture the cost of a 1 GB plan. It previously captured the cost of a 500 MB plan.

Description: Price of postpaid mobile data plan, 1 GB, as a percentage of monthly income
Notes: Monthly cost of a 1 GB postpaid mobile broadband data plan, expressed as a percentage of monthly GNI per capita. Note: This indicator was updated in the fourth edition to capture the cost of a 1 GB plan. It previously captured the cost of a 500 MB plan.

Source: ITU, National Statistics, Republic of China (Taiwan); ITU, UN; ITU, World Bank, WDI
Description: Price of fixed-line monthly broadband to the consumer as a percentage of monthly income
Notes: Fixed (wired)-broadband monthly subscription charge refers to the monthly subscription charge for fixed (wired); broadband Internet service. Fixed (wired) broadband is considered to be any dedicated connection to the Internet at; downstream speeds equal to;  or greater than;  256 kbit/s. If several offers are available;  preference should be given to; the 256 kbit/s connection. (in USD)

Source: Axiata; GSMA; GSMA Intelligence; ITU; TNM; Telegeography
Description: Average annual revenue per user (ARPU) for wireless operators
Notes: ARPU is the annual average revenue per user calculated over the given period (twelve months for annual data). ARPU is used to measure consumer spending on mobile services. This measure of ARPU is 'Blended_ which means that both pre-paid and post-paid subscribers are being counted in the metric. The metric includes data and voice.

Description: Measures the market concentration among all wireless operators. EIU calculates the Hirschman-Herfindahl Index which measures the concentration of markets as follows: HHI < 3,000 _unconcentrated_; HHI 3,000-4,000 _moderately concentrated_; HHI > 4,000 _highly concentrated_.
Notes: Wireless operators include those that provide 2G, 3G and 4G coverage via GSM, CDMA, W-CDMA, and LTE networks.

Description: Measures the market concentration among all broadband operators. EIU calculates the Hirschman-Herfindahl Index which measures the concentration of markets as follows: HHI < 3,000 _unconcentrated_; HHI 3,000-4,000 _moderately concentrated_; HHI > 4,000 _highly concentrated_.
Notes: Broadband operators include those that provide broadband via the following technologies: DSL, cable, fiber/LAN, and WiMax, and others (eg satellite, broadband over powerline).

IndicatorName: Availability of basic information in the local language
Description: Does the country have any domestic news websites that provide information online in local languages?
Notes: Assesses whether there is local news for the largest metropolitan area in local languages, including both official and non-official languages. For countries with more than one official language, the justification covers each of the official languages. Non-official languages may include native, indigenous or minority languages (eg, immigrant populations) commonly spoken but not recognized as official languages. The availability of online news in non-official languages can help to empower native and minority communities to produce their own culturally and locally relevant online content. Note: This indicator was updated in the fourth edition.  It was previously scored on a 0-2 scale. An additional scoring option has been included to reward countries with online news sites in non-official languages.
ZERO: No, there are no news websites in any official or non-official language(s)
ONE: Yes, there are news websites in some of the official languages
TWO: Yes, there are news websites in all official languages OR there is only one official language and there are news websites in this language BUT there are no news websites in non-official languages
THREE: Yes, there are news websites in all official languages OR there is only one official language and there are news websites in this language AND there are also news websites in at least one non-official language

IndicatorName: Concentration of websites using country-level domains
Description: What percent of websites in the top 25 most-visited websites use a ccTLD?
Notes: Top-level domains (TLDs) are set forth by the international organization, ICANN. TLDs with two letters (such as .de, .mx, and .jp) have been established for over 250 countries and external territories and are referred to as "country-code" TLDs or "ccTLDs". Importantly the significance is that, according to ICANN, ccTLDs are delegated to "designated managers, who operate the ccTLDs according to local policies that are adapted to best meet the economic, cultural, linguistic, and legal circumstances of the country or territory involved.
ZERO: No websites in the top 25 sites are local sites, or there is not enough data to determine the number of local sites
ONE: 1-2 websites out of the top 25 are local sites
TWO: 3-5 websites out of the top 25 are local sites
THREE: More than 5 of the top 25 websites are local sites

IndicatorName: Availability of e-Government services in the local language
Description: Does the government of the largest city in the country have a website that offers transactional services, including applying for a business license or permit?
Notes: Assesses whether there is a local government website available for the largest city in the country and whether the site offers transactional services that can include: applying for any type of license or permit, registering for programs/services and paying bills and fees. If the city website provides downloadable applications, but the process is not entirely online, the country scores a 1. In order to score a 2, the entire process must be online.
ZERO: No, the government of the largest city in the country does not have a website
ONE: Yes, the government of the largest city in the country does have a website but it does not allow for conducting transactional services online
TWO: Yes, the government of the largest city in the country does have a website and it does allow for conducting transactional services online

Description: Does the largest retail banking institution offer online banking services?
Notes: Assesses whether online banking services are offered by the largest retail bank by number of customers (retail and corporate). Online banking services must include, at a minimum, account access to view balances and transactions. In this question, Online is synonymous with mobile.
ZERO: No, the largest retail banking institution does not offer online banking services
ONE: Yes, the largest retail banking institution does offer basic online banking services
TWO: Yes, the largest retail banking institution does offer basic and advanced online banking services

Description: Which of the following forms of useful information have you accessed via the internet at least once in the last year?
Notes: Ranked by responses indicating 'Information about personal finance'

Description: Does the Ministry of Health in the country have a website that provides information or links to information regarding healthcare?
Notes: Assesses the existence of online healthcare information, and whether e-Health services are provided online (eg, the ability to sign up for insurance, search for a doctor, etc). Healthcare information topics may include: vaccinations and immunizations, tobacco free living; preventing drug and alcohol abuse; healthy lifestyles; reproductive health; mental and emotional well-being. Note: This indicator was updated in the fourth edition. Whereas the indicator previously assessed availability of information on _disease prevention and wellness_, it now assesses availability of information _regarding healthcare_ and also includes an additional assessment of e-Health services provision.
ZERO: No, the Ministry of Health does not have a website
ONE: Yes, the Ministry of Health has a website that provides limited information and/or links to information regarding healthcare
TWO: Yes, the Ministry of Health has a website that provides information and/or links to information regarding healthcare
THREE: Yes, the Ministry of Health has a website that provides information and/or links to information regarding healthcare and also offers e-Health services (eg, insurance enrolment, healthcare provider search, interactive mobile app)

Description: Which of the following forms of useful information have you accessed via the internet at least once in the last year?
Notes: Ranked by responses indicating 'Information about health and fitness'

Description: How often do you use the internet for entertainment purposes?
Notes: Ranked by responses indicating 'Several times a day', 'Every day' and 'Several times a week'

Description: Seeks to measure the availability _ and extent of _ electronic commerce (e-commerce) in the country, which can serve both as a service to buy products but also to sell them.
Notes: Greater availability of online services is generally seen as improving chances for adoption. Note: This indicator is based on the B2C E-Commerce Index, developed by UNCTAD. Given changes to the B2C E-Commerce Index over time (e.g., addition or removal of countries from year to year), scores for countries may not be directly comparable between different iterations. As a result, YoY comparisons for this indicator are not available in the Inclusive Internet Index.

Description: How often do you purchase goods via the internet?
Notes: Ranked by responses indicating 'About once a month'

Description: Does the government have an open data policy that applies to public sector data?
Notes: Assesses whether the government has a formal open data policy that applies to the public sector (i.e. the government makes public sector data_both public and publicly-funded data_publicly available to the general population), and whether the government has an open data website/platform that centralizes this data. Examples of an open data website/platform include https://www.data.gov/ (United States), https://data.gov.in/ (India), https://datos.gob.ar/ (Argentina). Note: This indicator was included for the first time in the fourth edition.
ZERO: No, the government does not have an open data policy that applies to public sector data
ONE: Yes, the government has an open data policy that applies to public sector data but has not developed an open data website/platform
TWO: Yes, the government has an open data policy that applies to public sector data and has an open data website/platform

Source: EIU; Social Indicators of Hong Kong; UNESCO
Description: Literate population over 15, expressed as a percentage of the total population
Notes: Assesses the extent of literacy within countries. In order to use the Internet for useful purposes, such as to read news, access health or educational information, people must have the ability to read.

Description: Mean years of schooling (ISCED 1 or higher)
Notes: Assesses educational attainment through average years of schooling (ISCED 1 or higher). Many studies show that adoption is higher among highly educated population groups.

Description: Does the government have a plan or strategy that addresses digital literacy for students and training for teachers?
Notes: Assesses the existence of a strategy that supports digital literacy whereby the government plan or strategy should address courses in ICT skills, computer science, programming, or other classes where computers are mandatory in the curriculum. The plan or strategy must also address training teachers on ICT skills.
ZERO: No, the government does not have a plan or strategy that addresses digital literacy for students and training for teachers
ONE: Yes, the government's plan or strategy addresses digital literacy for students, but it does not include training for teachers or the plan is outdated
TWO: Yes, the government's plan or strategy is current, addresses digital literacy for students and includes training for teachers
THREE: Yes, the government's plan or strategy is current, addresses digital literacy for students and includes training for teachers and is introduced at the primary school level

Description: Does the national government website pass W3C guidelines on web accessibility?
Notes: Assesses whether the main national government website is compliant. People with disabilities, such as sight impairment, may not be able to use websites if they are not accessible and adaptive. Being compliant with W3C guidelines, an international standard, greatly enhances the chance they can use websites.
ZERO: The national portal fails most tests or could not be tested (an EIII score of 0-69)
ONE: The national portal fails many tests (an EIII score of 70-84)
TWO: The national portal fails some tests (an EIII score of 85-94)
THREE: The national portal fails few tests (an EIII score of 95-99)
FOUR: The national portal fails no tests (an EIII score of 100)

Description: Does the country have data protection law(s) and are there legal or financial penalties in place for firms that do not follow the law?
Notes: Lack of clear privacy regulations can limit adoption if users feel their data and personal information is not secure online. Therefore it is important that the country has privacy laws, which enables users to know what is legally acceptable within the country.
ZERO: No, the country does not have data protection law(s)
ONE: Yes, the country does have data protection law(s) but there are no legal or financial penalties in place for firms that do not follow the law
TWO: Yes, the country does have data protection law(s) and there are legal or financial penalties in place for firms that do not follow the law

Description: How confident are you that your activity online is private?
Notes: Ranked by responses indicating 'Somewhat confident' and 'Very confident'

IndicatorName: Trust in Government websites and apps
Description: To what extent do you trust the information you receive from the following sources online? - 'Government websites / apps.' Ranked by responses indicating 'Mostly' and 'Completely'
Notes: Ranked by responses indicating 'Mostly' and 'Completely'

IndicatorName: Trust in Non-government websites and apps
Description: To what extent do you trust the information you receive from the following sources online? - 'Non-government websites / apps that are based in my country.'
Notes: Ranked by responses indicating 'Mostly' and 'Completely'

IndicatorName: Trust in information from social media
Description: To what extent do you trust the information you receive from the following sources online? - 'Other people using social media.'
Notes: Ranked by responses indicating 'Mostly' and 'Completely'

Description: To what extent do you agree with the following statements? - 'Making purchases online is safe and secure.'
Notes: Ranked by responses indicating 'Somewhat agree' and 'Strongly agree'

IndicatorName: National female e-inclusion policies: Comprehensive female e-inclusion plan
Description: Does the government have an active plan or strategy to promote Internet access and e-inclusion for females?
Notes: Assesses whether strategies addressing e-inclusion of females exist that help address gender digital divides. The indicator will examine whether e-inclusion strategies exist that address female Internet access and adoption. Countries that score a 2 on this indicator have gender parity or a gender gap that is below the 10% threshold, regardless of an e-inclusion plan targeting women. Countries that score a 1 on this indicator have an e-inclusion policy but the gender gap is above the 10% threshold. The EIU determined that the scoring thresholds should be based on a gender gap ratio of at least 10% based on data analysis as well as metrics used by ITU and GSMA to measure the gender gap.
ZERO: No, the government does not have an active plan or strategy to promote internet access and e-inclusion for females, and the gender gap in internet access is greater than 10%
ONE: Yes, the government has an active plan or strategy to promote internet access and e-inclusion for females, but the gender gap in internet access is greater than 10%
TWO: Yes, the government has an active plan or strategy to promote internet access and e-inclusion for females, and / or there is gender parity or the gap between male and female internet access is less than 10%

IndicatorName: National female e-inclusion policies: Female digital skills training plan
Description: Does the government have an action plan to provide digital skills training for women?
Notes: Assesses whether strategies addressing e-inclusion of females exist that help address gender digital divides. The indicator will examine whether e-inclusion strategies exist that address digital skills training for women.
ZERO: No, the government does not have an action plan or strategy to provide digital skills training for women
ONE: Yes, the government has an action plan or strategy to provide digital skills training for women

IndicatorName: National female e-inclusion policies: Female STEM education plan
Description: Does the government have a policy in place that encourages women and girls to study STEM?
Notes: Assesses whether policies or government initiatives exist that encourage the study of STEM fields for females.
ZERO: No, the government does not have a policy to promote STEM education for females
ONE: Yes, the government has a policy to promote STEM education for females

Description: Does the government have any current initiatives or strategies in place that address e-inclusion _ the inclusion and promotion of Internet access for underserved groups?
Notes: Assesses whether the country has any initiatives or plans that address e-inclusion. Underserved groups include: Elderly; Youth; Low-income; Women; Ethnic minorities; Disabled.
ZERO: The government does not have any current initiatives or strategies in place that address Internet access for underserved groups
ONE: The government has current initiatives or strategies in place that address Internet access for 1-2 underserved groups
TWO: The government has current initiatives or strategies in place that address Internet access for more than 3 underserved groups

Description: Does the government have a current national broadband strategy?
Notes: Assesses whether or not the country has a current national broadband strategy. _Current_ means that the national strategy has been published or updated within the past two years or within the past five years, with a higher score being give to the former. Note: This indicator was updated in the fourth edition. Whereas the indicator previously assessed the presence of a national broadband strategy and whether or not the strategy included a target penetration rate, it now assesses the status of a national broadband strategy (i.e., is there a strategy and is it current?) that is technology neutral (i.e., the strategy may emphasize fixed broadband or mobile broadband, or both).
ZERO: No, the government does not have a national broadband strategy
ONE: Yes, the government has a national broadband strategy, but it was not published within the past 5 years
TWO: Yes, the government has a national broadband strategy that was published within the past 5 years
THREE: Yes, the government has a national broadband strategy that was published within the past 2 years

Description: Do government programs exist to help subsidize or provide incentives for broadband buildout in underserved areas?
Notes: Assesses whether the country has an active government program(s) that helps subsidize or incentivize the buildout of broadband networks. Revised from an indicator only looking at Universal Service Funds (USF) as a method for improving broadband buildout, this indicator expands the scope of the question by addressing other financing options including USFs, in addition to tax credits, low-interest loans, and other government funding sources. This indicator helps address the principle that all citizens should have access to a baseline level of telecommunications services within a country.
ZERO: No, government programs do not exist to help subsidize or provide incentives for broadband buildout in underserved areas
ONE: Yes, government programs exist to help subsidize or provide incentives for broadband buildout in underserved areas

IndicatorName: Spectrum policy approach: Technology-neutrality policy for spectrum use
Description: Does the country have a policy that addresses technology-neutrality for spectrum use?
Notes: Assesses the country's ability to expand broadband connectivity by way of gauging operator flexibility within a country's spectrum policy to migrate to the next generation of network technology. Higher prices, poorer service, lost productivity, loss of competitive advantage and untapped innovation can all be outcomes of preventing flexibility. Technology Neutrality is a policy approach that allows the use of any technology in any spectrum band. That means, with technology neutrality in place, mobile operators can offer services through any technology (2G/3G/4G/LTE) using any of the frequencies in their possessions ("refarming"). The freedom to deploy network of any technology using the available spectrum brings overall efficiency which culminates to benefits of mobile phone users of this country.
ZERO: No, the government does not have a technology-neutrality policy for spectrum use
ONE: Yes, the government has a technology-neutrality policy for spectrum use

IndicatorName: Spectrum policy approach: Unlicensed spectrum policy
Description: Does the country have a policy that addresses using unlicensed spectrum for greater wi-fi access?
Notes: Assesses the country's ability to expand broadband connectivity by way of assessing the country's openness to provisioning unlicensed spectrum for greater wi-fi access and other productive uses. Higher prices, poorer service, lost productivity, loss of competitive advantage and untapped innovation can all be outcomes of preventing flexibility.
ZERO: No, the government does not have a policy that addresses the use of unlicensed spectrum for greater wi-fi access
ONE: Yes, the government has a policy that addresses the use of unlicensed spectrum for greater wi-fi access

Description: Does the country have a national digital identification (e-ID) system to be used online to access government services?
Notes: Assesses whether the country has a national digital identification system.
ZERO: No National ID
ONE: National ID exists but it is NOT e-ID
TWO: National ID exists and it IS e-ID (at least partially)

Description: Has the government developed a policy, strategy or initiatives to promote 5G?
Notes: Assesses whether the country has developed a strategy or initiatives to promote 5G. Countries receive a higher score if the policy or strategy recognizes multiple use cases of 5G. Multiple use cases may include the following: fixed wireless access (FWA), enhanced mobile broadband (eMBB), massive machine-type communications (mMTC), Internet of Things (IoT) or ultra-reliable low-latency communications (URLLC). Other use cases or applications may also apply if specifically mentioned (eg. 5G for precision agriculture, smart city/home applications, autonomous vehicle applications). Note that policies, strategies or initiatives may be embodied across a number of documents (eg, policy or strategy documents, government committee notes). This indicator was included for the first time in the fourth edition.
ZERO: No, the government has not developed a policy, strategy or initiatives to promote 5G
ONE: Yes, the government has developed a policy, strategy or initiatives to promote 5G but does not specifically mention any of the following use-case applications (FWA, eMBB, mMTC, IoT, URLLC)
TWO: Yes, the government has a policy, strategy or initiatives to promote 5G and specifically mentions one of the following use-case applications (FWA, eMBB, mMTC, IoT, URLLC)
THREE: Yes, the government has a policy or strategy to promote 5G network development and it specifically mentions more than one of the following use-case applications (FWA, eMBB, mMTC, IoT, URLLC)

Description: Measures the total economic value of a country
Notes: Countries with higher GDP typically have higher purchasing power for ICT.

Description: Measures the population of the country
Measures the percentage of the population living in urban areas

Source: National Statistics, Republic of China (Taiwan); UN; World Bank, WDI
Description: Measures gross national income per capita (Atlas method)
Notes: Higher income increases the chances for affordability of access.

Unit: Score, 0-100; 0 is perfect equality; 100 is perfect inequality
Source: CIA World Factbook; EIU; World Bank
Description: Measures the income distribution (inequality) by country
Notes: Gini index measures the extent to which the distribution of income (or, in some cases, consumption expenditure) among individuals or households within an economy deviates from a perfectly equal distribution. A Lorenz curve plots the cumulative percentages of total income received against the cumulative number of recipients, starting with the poorest individual or household. The Gini index measures the area between the Lorenz curve and a hypothetical line of absolute equality, expressed as a percentage of the maximum area under the line. Thus a Gini index of 0 represents perfect equality, while an index of 100 implies perfect inequality.

Description: Measures the percentage of the population living under the poverty line at $1.90/day
Notes: Poverty gap at $1.90 a day (2011 PPP) is the mean shortfall in income or consumption from the poverty line $1.90 a day (counting the nonpoor as having zero shortfall), expressed as a percentage of the poverty line. This measure reflects the depth of poverty as well as its incidence. As a result of revisions in PPP exchange rates, poverty rates for individual countries cannot be compared with poverty rates reported in earlier editions.

Source: WEO-IEA; World Bank; World Energy Council
Description: Total population with access to electricity
Notes: Access to electricity is the percentage of population with access to electricity. Electrification data are collected from industry, national surveys and international sources.

Unit: Number of cable landing stations per 10 million inhabitants
Description: Measures the number of cable landing stations in each country
Notes: Cable landing stations are the pieces of network infrastructure where submarine cables make landfall. Landlocked countries do not have access to cable landing stations. As such, landlocked countries receive the simple average of all countries in the series.

IndicatorName: Percentage of schools with Internet access
Source: EIU; ITU; Ministry of Education and Science; NCC; Statistics Canada; UNESCO
Description: What percentage of secondary schools in the country have access to the internet?
Notes: The proportion of secondary educational institutions with any type of Internet connection, whereby the Internet is defined as: worldwide interconnected networks that enable users to share information in an interactive format _ referred to as hypertext _ through multiple wired or wireless devices (personal computers, laptops, PDAs, smartphones, etc.) via broadband and narrowband connections. Where data gaps existed, data on primary educational institutions were collected.

Source: EIU; Institute for Economics and Peace
Description: A framework for understanding the drivers of sustainable peace.
A framework for measuring the quality of democracy and the biggest threats to sustaining democracy.
Measures the perceived levels of public sector corruption worldwide
Measures ten separate criteria or categories on the health of the business environment
Notes: The EIUs business environment rankings quantify the attractiveness of the business environment. The business rankings model examines ten separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market and infrastructure.

Source: EIU; UN E-Government Development Index score

Gap between female and male access to the Internet in percentage points
Notes:
This indicator is an alternative measure of the gap in internet access between male and females. This indicator measures the difference in access between males and females in percentage points.

Positive number = males have better access, negative number = females have better access, zero = parity.

Description: Gap between female and male access to mobile phone in percentage points
Notes:
This indicator is an alternative measure of the gap in mobile phone access between male and females. This indicator measures the difference in access between males and females in percentage points.

Positive number = males have better access, negative number = females have better access, zero = parity.
